description.narrative:
Activists Organization for Development and Human Rights (AODHR) was created during the uprisings in Yemen and officially became registered in 2012. The organisation is based in Taiz. AODHR seeks establishing the principles of human rights and spread themorals ofco-existence and tolerance. They focus on two important issues, one of them protecting children from the dangers and risks they face, the other one supporting women and qualifying them in order to reach decision-making positions to be a partnerin various aspects of life efficiently and effectively.
Under the Women on the Frontline programme the following outcomes are planned for the proposedproject period: - 60 young women leaders have been trained and have the required skills and abilitieson political rights, leadership and negotiation to realize advocacy and mobilization campaigns. - Through radio and TV episodes about million people in Taiz have listened to information related to women rights and the most important issues that shouldbereflected in the (new) laws. - 3 silent marches and 2 wall drawing activities related to women rights and to support women’s participation in public life have mobilized participation of the wider community in Taiz. - 80 people (male and female activists, media personnel, lawyers, leaders ) have participated in the dialogue forums and submitted their opinions on what should be included in the new laws. - An overview of legal suggestions and adaptations has been drafted in relation to laws such as the personal status law, penal code, labor and the elections system to ensure they are gender sensitive.

participating-org.narrative: Activists Organization for Developm and Human Rights

Background Women on the Frontline Programme: The events in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) have shaken the world. Unprecedented civic uprisings have ousted dictators who had been in power for decades. The transitions are still unfolding and old structuresare being challenged, while new foundations of civic engagement are being laid. However, the uprisings also generated major challenges for women. The first negative impacts are already visible. There is a decrease in the political representation of women after the fall of the dictatorships in Egypt and Tunisia, an increase in gender based violence (GBV) is reported in all countries in transition. And there is a tendency towards more conservative interpretations of the Islamic sharia-law, which mostly affects women and negatively impacts the exercise of their rights. On the other hand, initiatives, organisations and coalitions addressing the role and participation of women in the uprisings and in society as a whole are flourishing.
The Women on the Frontline programme is one of the initiatives that aims to support women’s rights in the MENA region within the ongoing transitions. The programme considers this tobe crucial in preventing regression of acquired rights and promoting the improvement of rights for women. This Programme is funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Overall objective of the Programme: “To contribute to the full and equal participation ofwomen in transforming societies in the Middle East and North Africa (Syria, Libya, Iraq, Bahrein, Tunisia, Yemen & Egypt) Long termprogramme objectives:
1. Women’s organisations / women’s focussed initiatives address the need for gender equality in constitution, legislation and policies and demand for their implementation. 2. Women’s organisations / women’s focussed initiatives advocate forincreased representation of women in decision making processes.polici 3. Women’s organisations / women’s focussed initiatives contribute to the public debate on gender equality and women’s participation in political and civic processes.
The programme offers longer term investment in building the capacities of emerging local women’s organisations and women’s focussed initiatives to contribute to gender equality and women’s empowerment in the transition phases. Additionally, the Programme also offers an opportunity to demonstrate women’s perseverance and leadership in upholding the Universal Declaration of Human rights, CEDAW and other international conventions.
The Programme therefore offers capacity building support in the areas of: 1. organisational development: broad organisational and content capacity building 2. developing legal skills and knowledge to demand for and contribute to gender sensitive constitutional, legal and policy reform. 3. developing skills and knowledge to demand for and contribute to full and equal participation in political and civic processes. 4. undertaking civic education and awareness raising initiatives to promote and practice gender equality.
The main implementing partners of the programme are Hivos , Price Waterhouse Coopers and Oxfam Novib. The countries where this program will be implemented are: Syria, Libya, Iraq, Bahrein (HIVOS), Tunisia, Yemen & Egypt (Oxfam Novib).
